sapphics 162798122497 "2017-07-09 21:49:31 GMT" http://sapphics.tumblr.com/post/162798122497/gay-caesar-so-theres-a-story-from-my-life-that "gay-caesar: so thereâ€™s a story from my life that i think a lot of inclusionists would benefit from hearing. this story starts about four years ago
column2: when fifteen year old me
column3: still thinking i was bi and knowing fervently as hell that I Am Trans. i had a terrible
column5: and i decided one day i was going to go to my schoolâ€™s gsa meeting. now at this point iâ€™m out to one person in the whole world
column6: and iâ€™m fucking shaking as i walk into this shitty public school classroom that hasnâ€™t changed pretty much at all since like 1962. that first time
column7: i sat on a desk in the back row shaking like a leaf and didnâ€™t say a word to anyone.  but that year
column10: and they smiled at me and wore batman boxers and went to glsen meetings in the city on the weekend
column11: and slowly i learned that not only could it be ok to be trans
column12: it could be amazing. but that is not the point of this story. the point of this story is that that year
column13: i felt safe. there were gay adults there who made sure we were all safe
column14: and other gay kids who had fought tooth and nail and carved out this club from the highschool that didnâ€™t want to give it to them. sure
column15: there were one or two straight kids
column17: and they sure as hell were never excluded. they didnâ€™t feel the need to take up extra space
column18: or make sure everyone knew they were Straight. they were there because their friends were there
column19: or they really believed in the cause
column20: even if it was just giving a group of suburban gay kids a safe room. and much like the exclusionist/inclusionist discourse
column21: there was never a concentrated effort on either part to other each other- until there absolutely was. my junior year
column22: our gsa president was a cishet guy. in case anyone i know reads this
column23: iâ€™ll call him harry. harry was a great guy
column24: and he really believed in lgbt rights. he shouldnâ€™t have been president
column25: though. because once we made the â€œfaceâ€ of the lgbt movement in our school a straight guy
column26: it suddenly became cool to come to gsa meetings if you were a straight kid. and believe me
column27: you knew who was gay and who wasnâ€™t when you walked in that room. the straight kids would stumble in in packs of four or five
column28: and always sit by the window
column29: eating most of the food and laughing and whispering to themselves. they talked over us
column30: and when i (one of the two vice presidents) ran the meetings
column31: you could feel the giant question mark in the air. more than once
column33: flounder about with their hands even though i had already told everyone my pronouns
column35: had someone actually ARGUE with me when i said i used he/him. in the gsa. the one club in the entire school for lgbt kids. someone told me i was straight up wrong- that i wasnâ€™t a guy.  and of course
column36: it would be disingenuous to not talk about my own bully joining the gsa. joining maybe isnâ€™t the word- he was there before me
column37: and left before i joined- but he came back. and of course
column38: having the one insanely openly gay kid
column39: the one who leered at guys in the changing rooms
column40: and watched rupaul like a religion
column41: who was transphobic and thought being a drag queen made you trans
column42: who thought being bi was fake
column43: and was loud and open and vocal about all these things
column44: that made a difference in the tone of the room. walking into that room became more stressful then almost anything i did. i had two eating disorders
column48: and had to deal with my abuser all weekend
column49: and walking into that room was the one thing that made my shoulders hunch in on themselves. because in that room
column51: and nearly everyone either thought i was wrong
column52: or thought that was a fun party trick. you can imagine how welcoming it felt for 14 or 15 year old lgbt kids. slowly
column54: including one of the co-presidents. she was a lesbian of color in a school of almost all white straight kids. in what should have been the one place in school where she could talk about that
column55: she instead had to bottle it up and trade it in for leaving and never talking about it. the next year
column56: it was even worse. the president was cishet; the vice president was cishet. the cool gay adults who had cared about us and tried so hard to make us safe had hung up the towel
column57: and instead two cishet teachers sat in with us. one of them refused to allow any gay interpretations of her curriculum
column58: and actually gave one of my friends a bad grade on a paper because she argued there were gay undertones in a seperate peace. the other thought that my bullyâ€™s jokes about mexican people clamoring to marry americans at the airports (a joke that left my friend in tears when they heard it) was hilarious. the room was full of straight people. occasionally
column59: a few of my friends would come with me
column60: but mostly we would leave early. the cishet freshmen got into fights with the lgbt freshmen
column61: and the lgbt freshmen stopped coming. it took less than three years for a safe space to become an almost all straight club
column62: all of them piling into a room to laugh at the racist gay kidâ€™s jokes
column63: or to gawk at the rest of us. some of you might say â€œthat was a small highschool club
column64: â€ and youâ€™re right!  but this isnâ€™t a small problem. when you let cishet people into the lgbt community as anything other than staunch
column66: you start taking away lgbt peopleâ€™s voices. and weâ€™ve seen this already. cishet aces got representation at pride this year
column67: while lgbt poc couldnâ€™t talk about how theyâ€™re being abused
column68: assaulted and murdered at higher rates than any other part of our community. online
column69: tumblr posted pictures of the ace flag
column70: but excluded the lesbian flag. i understand that you think you really do belong in our community
column71: but you donâ€™t. you deserve your own community
column72: where you feel safe. where you donâ€™t have to argue with us
column73: where you can talk about the issues you face. but that isnâ€™t with us
column74: clearly.  and taking away our voices isnâ€™t going to make yours any louder." False text

column1: sapphics 161565183347 "2017-06-08 01:19:17 GMT" http://sapphics.tumblr.com/post/161565183347/why-were-terrified-of-fanfiction "insomniac-arrest:  crowfoot:  whovianfeminism:  playerprophet: Stands up on soapbox
column2: holds up this article like itâ€™s the opening of the Lion King. Yâ€™all should read this because it is FIRE
column3: but also because a post from the Time Lady Project was linked in this!   Historically
column4: whenever young women are interested in a form of media
column5: we like to tell them it is bad for them and that they are bad for  liking it â€” unless the media goes mainstream
column6: in which case it becomes  no longer feminine and hence okay. Novels are dangerous and cause  insanity
